item.title: Amazon to Retrain a Third of Its U.S. Workforce
item.description: Amazon.com plans to spend $700 million to retrain a third of its U.S. workforce, as technology threatens to upend the way many of its employees do their jobs.

item.title: U.S. to Probe France's Digital Tax
item.description: The U.S. is launching an investigation of France’s planned tax on digital services, marking the first major confrontation as leading economies examine ways to tax the internet economy.

item.title: Apple Pulls Watch App After Finding Eavesdropping Glitch
item.description: Apple has disabled the Walkie-Talkie app on Apple Watches after finding a glitch that could allow a person to listen in on someone else’s iPhone call, the second eavesdropping flaw Apple has addressed in recent months.

item.title: The Clinic That Helps Seniors Find the Right Marijuana Treatment
item.description: More older people are trying cannabis to alleviate pain and other ailments, but they’re often left taking medical advice from dispensary sales clerks. NiaMedic wants to change that.

item.title: France Presses On With Digital Tax Despite U.S. Probe
item.description: France’s legislature gave final approval to a new tax on large tech companies, shrugging off the threat posed by a new U.S. trade probe into whether the measure discriminates against American firms.

item.title: PC Shipments Rise After Several Quarters of Decline
item.description: Personal-computer shipments rose in the second quarter for the first time since last year, as businesses sought upgrades to technology with new Windows 10 software and a shortage in processors eased.

item.title: Mnuchin Urges Suppliers to Seek Huawei Exemptions
item.description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin in recent days urged U.S. suppliers of Huawei Technologies to seek exemptions to resume sales to the blacklisted Chinese firm.

item.title: Trump Administration Hasn't Briefed Congress on New Cyberattack Rules, Lawmakers Say
item.description: The Trump administration hasn’t allowed Congress to see a classified directive issued by President Trump almost a year ago that outlines new rules for cyber weapons, prompting concern among some lawmakers that they lack oversight of the military’s increasing use of cyberattacks.

item.title: Japan's Restrictions on South Korean Chip Makers Backfire
item.description: Japan’s trade jab at South Korea’s chip makers was meant to be painful, but a week in, it appears to have given a momentary victory to the core targets: Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix.

item.title: Nintendo Moves Forward with a Cheaper Switch Console
item.description: Nintendo says it will start selling a cheaper version of its Switch videogame console in September, a move aimed at boosting sales for its more than two-year-old game system.

item.title: Computers Can Now Bluff Like a Poker Champ. Better, Actually.
item.description: A new artificial intelligence program called Pluribus is so advanced at a key human skill—deception—that it wiped out five human poker players with one lousy hand. ‘Hopeless.’

item.title: Google Contractors Listen to Virtual-Assistant Conversations
item.description: Google said contractors are listening to customer audio recorded by the company’s virtual assistant, a disclosure prompted by a media report that adds to privacy concerns associated with the voice-operated devices.

item.title: Fed's Powell Says Facebook's Libra Raises 'Serious Concerns'
item.description: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell and legislators in both parties expressed broad concern about Facebook’s plan to create a cryptocurrency-based payment network.

item.title: Newbies Pay $15 Million for TV Episode to Stand Out in Packed Streaming Market
item.description: As Walt Disney, AT&T’s WarnerMedia and Apple prepare to enter the crowded streaming-entertainment market, they are racing to stand out with eye-catching shows that cost as much for a season as a big-budget movie.

item.title: Should an Instant Camera Let You Edit Before You Print?
item.description: With Fujifilm’s Mini LiPlay, you can select and filter an image before it spits out. But some say digital tricks compromise what makes instant cameras great.

item.title: Big Tech Is a Likely Target at White House Social-Media Summit
item.description: A “Social Media Summit” at the White House this week will offer a platform for Trump supporters who say they face censorship by left-tilting Big Tech—and a preview of a likely re-election theme for the president.

item.title: SEC Clears Blockstack to Hold First Regulated Token Offering
item.description: The Securities and Exchange Commission cleared blockchain startup Blockstack to sell bitcoin-like digital tokens, a first-of-its-kind offering that could give young cryptocurrency businesses a new fundraising template.

item.title: Trump's 'Social Media Summit' Airs Grievances Against Big Tech
item.description: President Trump used a “Social Media Summit” at the White House to bond with some of his most provocative supporters over shared grievances against large technology companies whose representatives weren’t invited.

item.title: McAfee Readies Return to Public Markets
item.description: Cybersecurity-software company McAfee is planning to return to the public markets, joining a record rush of IPOs.

item.title: Videogames and Two-Day Delivery Powered the S&P's Rise to 3000
item.description: Tech stocks including Amazon.com and Netflix led the pack during the S&P 500’s half-decade march from 2000 to 3000, while oil companies were among the laggards.

item.title: Apple Music, Spotify Tap Live Events to Stand Out
item.description: Streaming services are using listening data to invite hard-core fans to free, private concerts by Taylor Swift, Tyler the Creator and other pop stars to stand out and connect with fans more directly.

item.title: Who Needs Amazon HQ2? Not New York Real Estate's Tech Boom
item.description: Technology companies are adding millions of square feet in office space and creating thousands of local jobs, with few repercussions from Amazon’s rejection of a Queens headquarters.

item.title: Spurred by Amazon, Supermarkets Try Swapping Cashiers for Cameras
item.description: Tesco and other supermarket chains are testing cashierless stores with cameras that track what shoppers pick, so they pay by simply walking out the door.

item.title: After Jony Ive, Apple Bets a Pragmatist Can Turn Prophet
item.description: Apple’s Jeff Williams has gone from heading procurement to leading all of the tech giant’s operations. Now he has a new responsibility: creating the iconic gadgets that make the company hum.
